However, in some cases, the server is actually honest and wants to obtain a meaningful result—this motivates the need of having the protocol be robust against malicious clients in addition to the other security properties. In Section 3.2, we discussed that in BBGLR, when the server is honest, a malicious client who deviates from the protocol may cause the output to be wrong or the protocol to abort (without being detected). The attack is simple: a malicious client changes the received share of a secret, and if the server cannot reconstruct the secret then the protocol aborts; or the server may reconstruct to another secret. The protocol we give in Section 4 does not have robustness for the same reason as in BBGLR, but we provide an extension such that the malicious behavior of the clients can be detected. The full description of the extension is given in Appendix E.1.

As a result, the extended protocol always terminates with the correct output (i.e., the sum of the inputs from clients who participated) when the server is honest; if the server is malicious, then the protocol either aborts or outputs a sum from at least (1−δ−η)​|St|1𝛿𝜂subscript𝑆𝑡(1-\delta-\eta)|S_{t}| clients. That said, we want to emphasize that this difference in security is not practically meaningful at the moment since malicious clients are free to provide any input they want (see the paragraph on input correctness in §2.4). However, it could become important in the future: if there is ever some mechanism that could confirm the validity of clients’ inputs, then this additional guarantee would ensure that an honest server always gets valid outputs even if malicious clients exist in the system.

10 Related Work

In this section we discuss alternative approaches to compute private sums and the reasons why they do not fit well in the setting of federated learning. Readers may also be interested in a recent survey of this area [51].

Pairwise masking. Bonawitz et al. [11] and follow up works [9, 65], of which BBGLR [9] is the state-of-the-art, adopt the idea of DC networks [22] in which pairwise masks are used to hide individuals’ inputs. Such a construction is critical for both client-side and server-side efficiency: first, since the vectors are long, one-time pad is the most efficient way to encrypt a vector; second, the server just needs to add up the vectors, which achieves optimal server computation (even without privacy, the server at least has to do a similar sum). Furthermore, pairwise masking protocols support flexible input vectors, i.e., one can choose any b𝑏b (the number of bits for each component in the vector) as desired. Flamingo improves on this line of work by reducing the overall round trip complexity for multiple sums.

MPC. Works like FastSecAgg [42] use a secret-sharing based MPC to compute sums, which tolerates dropouts, but it has high communication as the inputs in federated learning are large. Other results use non-interactive MPC protocols for addition [66, 65] where all the clients establish shares of zero during the setup. And then when the vectors of clients are requested, each client uses the share to mask the vector and sends it to the server. However, to mask long vectors, the clients need to establish many shares of zeros, which is communication-expensive. Such shares cannot be reused over multiple summation rounds (which is precisely what we address with Flamingo). Furthermore, the non-interactive protocols are not resilient against even one dropout client.

Additively homomorphic encryption. One can construct a single-server aggregation protocol using threshold additive homomorphic encryption [29, 54, 58, 59, 69, 27]. Each client encrypts its vector as a ciphertext under the public key of the threshold scheme, and sends it to the committee. The committee adds the ciphertexts from all the clients and gives the result to the server. However, this does not work well for large inputs (like the large weight vectors found in federated learning) because encrypting the vector (say, using Paillier or a lattice-based scheme) and performing the threshold decryption will be very expensive.

A recent work [67] uses LWE-based homomorphic PRGs. This is an elegant approach but it has higher computation and communication costs than works based on pairwise masking, including Flamingo. The higher cost stems from one having to choose parameters (e.g., vector length and the size of each component) that satisfy the LWE assumption, and particularly the large LWE modulus that is required.

Multi-round setting. Recent work [36] designs a new multi-round secure aggregation protocol with reusable secrets that is very different from Flamingo’s design. The protocol works well for small input domains (e.g., vectors with small values) but cannot efficiently handle large domains as it requires brute forcing a discrete log during decryption. In contrast, Flamingo does not have any restriction on the input domain. A variant of the above work can also accommodate arbitrary input domains by relying on DDH-based class groups [19] (a more involved assumption than DDH).

11 Discussion

We have focused our discussion on computing sums, but Flamingo can also compute other functions such as max/min using affine aggregatable encodings [8, 24, 38, 4].

Limitations. Flamingo assumes that the set of all clients (N)𝑁(N) involved in a training session is fixed before the training starts and that in each round t𝑡t some subset Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t} from N𝑁N is chosen. We have not yet explored the case of handling clients that dynamically join the training session.

Another aspect that we have not investigated in this work is that of handling an adaptive adversary that can dynamically change the set of parties that it compromises as the protocol executes. In BBGLR, the adversary can be adaptive across rounds but not within a round; in Flamingo the adversary is static across all the rounds. To our knowledge, an adversary that can be adaptive within a single round has not been considered before in the federating learning setting. It is not clear that existing approaches from other fields [34] can be used due to different communication models.

Finally, secure aggregation reduces the leakage of individuals’ inputs in federated learning but does not fully eliminate it. It is important to understand what information continues to leak. Two recent works in this direction are as follows. Elkordy et al. [30] utilize tools from information theory to bound the leakage with secure aggregation: they found that the amount of leakage reduces linearly with the number of clients. Wang et al. [73] then show a new inference attack against federated learning systems that use secure aggregation in which they are able to obtain the proportion of different labels in the overall training data. While the scope of this attack is very limited, it may inspire more advanced attacks.

Appendix A Failure and threat model details

In this section, we give the full details of the dropout rate and the corruption rate (§2.3).

Dropout rate. Recall that we upper bound the dropout rate of the sum contributors (Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t}) in one round as δ𝛿\delta. For decryptors, we consider the dropout rate in one summation round and assume it is at most δDsubscript𝛿𝐷\delta_{D}. Note that δ𝛿\delta and δDsubscript𝛿𝐷\delta_{D} are individually determined by the server timeout at those steps (recall that in each round, clients in Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t} only participate in the first step; the following two steps only involve decryptors).

Corruption rate. For corruption, we denote the corrupted rate in Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t} as ηStsubscript𝜂subscript𝑆𝑡\eta_{S_{t}} and the corrupted rate in decryptors as ηDsubscript𝜂𝐷\eta_{D}. In the Flamingo system, η𝜂\eta is given; ηStsubscript𝜂subscript𝑆𝑡\eta_{S_{t}} and ηDsubscript𝜂𝐷\eta_{D} depends on η𝜂\eta. Note that the fraction of malicious clients in a chosen subset of [N]delimited-[]𝑁[N] (e.g., Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t}, 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}) may not be exactly η𝜂\eta, but rather a random variable η∗superscript𝜂\eta^{*} from a distribution that is parameterized by η𝜂\eta, N𝑁N and the size of the chosen set. Since the expectation of η∗superscript𝜂\eta^{*} is equal to η𝜂\eta, and when the size of the chosen set is large (e.g., Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t}), the deviation of η∗superscript𝜂\eta^{*} from η𝜂\eta is negligible (i.e., η∗superscript𝜂\eta^{*} is almost equal to η𝜂\eta). Therefore, ηStsubscript𝜂subscript𝑆𝑡\eta_{S_{t}} can be considered as equal to η𝜂\eta. On the other hand, since 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} is a small set, we cannot assume ηDsubscript𝜂𝐷\eta_{D} is equal to η𝜂\eta. Later in Appendix C we show how to choose L𝐿L to ensure ηDsubscript𝜂𝐷\eta_{D} satisfies the inequality required in Theorem 3 with overwhelming probability.

Security parameters. In the following definitions and proofs, we use κ𝜅\kappa for the information-theoretic security parameter and λ𝜆\lambda for the computational security parameter.

Appendix B Full Protocol Description

B.1 Definition of cryptographic primitives

In this section, we formally define the cryptographic primitives used in Flamingo protocol that are not given in Section 3.1.

Definition 1 (DDH assumption).

Given a cyclic group 𝔾𝔾\mathbb{G} with order q𝑞q, and let the generator of 𝔾𝔾\mathbb{G} be g𝑔g. Let a,b,c𝑎𝑏𝑐a,b,c be uniformly sampled elements from ℤqsubscriptℤ𝑞\mathbb{Z}_{q}. We say that DDH is hard if the two distributions (ga,gb,ga​b)superscript𝑔𝑎superscript𝑔𝑏superscript𝑔𝑎𝑏(g^{a},g^{b},g^{ab}) and (ga,gb,gc)superscript𝑔𝑎superscript𝑔𝑏superscript𝑔𝑐(g^{a},g^{b},g^{c}) are computationally indistinguishable.

Definition 2 (ElGamal encryption).

Let 𝔾𝔾\mathbb{G} be a group of order q𝑞q in which DDH is hard. ElGamal encryption scheme consists of the following three algorithms.

  • •

    AsymGen​(1λ)→(S​K,P​K)→AsymGensuperscript1𝜆𝑆𝐾𝑃𝐾\textrm{AsymGen}(1^{\lambda})\rightarrow(SK,PK): sample a random element s𝑠s from ℤqsubscriptℤ𝑞\mathbb{Z}_{q}, and output S​K=s𝑆𝐾𝑠SK=s and P​K=gs𝑃𝐾superscript𝑔𝑠PK=g^{s}.

  • •

    AsymEnc​(P​K,h)→(cΓ,c1)→AsymEnc𝑃𝐾ℎsubscript𝑐Γsubscript𝑐1\textrm{AsymEnc}(PK,h)\rightarrow(c_{0},c_{1}): sample a random element y𝑦y from ℤqsubscriptℤ𝑞\mathbb{Z}_{q} and compute cΓ=gysubscript𝑐Γsuperscript𝑔𝑦c_{0}=g^{y} and c1=h⋅P​Kysubscript𝑐1⋅ℎ𝑃superscript𝐾𝑦c_{1}=h\cdot PK^{y}.

  • •

    AsymDec​(S​K,(cΓ,c1))→h→AsymDec𝑆𝐾subscript𝑐Γsubscript𝑐1ℎ\textrm{AsymDec}(SK,(c_{0},c_{1}))\rightarrow h: compute h=(cΓS​K)−1⋅c1ℎ⋅superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑐Γ𝑆𝐾1subscript𝑐1h=(c_{0}^{SK})^{-1}\cdot c_{1}.

We say that ElGamal encryption is secure if it has CPA security. Note that if DDH assumption (Def.1) holds, then ElGamal encryption is secure.

Definition 3 (Authenticated encryption).

An authenticated encryption scheme consists of the following algorithms:

  • •

    SymAuthGen​(1λ)→k→SymAuthGensuperscript1𝜆𝑘\textrm{SymAuthGen}(1^{\lambda})\rightarrow k: sample a key k𝑘k uniformly random from {Γ,1}λsuperscriptΓ1𝜆\{0,1\}^{\lambda}.

  • •

    SymAuthEnc​(k,m)→c→SymAuthEnc𝑘𝑚𝑐\textrm{SymAuthEnc}(k,m)\rightarrow c: take in a key k𝑘k and a message m𝑚m, output a ciphertext c𝑐c.

  • •

    SymAuthDec​(k,c)SymAuthDec𝑘𝑐\textrm{SymAuthDec}(k,c): take in a key k𝑘k and a ciphertext c𝑐c, output a plaintext m𝑚m or ⟂perpendicular-to\perp (decryption fails).

We say that the scheme is secure if it has CPA security and ciphertext integrity.

For simplicity, we use AsymEnc and SymAuthEnc to refer to the encryption schemes.

Definition 4 (Signature scheme).

A signature scheme consists of the following algorithms:

  • •

    S​G​e​n​(1λ)→(s​k,p​k)→𝑆𝐺𝑒𝑛superscript1𝜆𝑠𝑘𝑝𝑘SGen(1^{\lambda})\rightarrow(sk,pk): generate a pair of siging key s​k𝑠𝑘sk and verfication key p​k𝑝𝑘pk.

  • •

    S​i​g​n​(s​k,m)→σ→𝑆𝑖𝑔𝑛𝑠𝑘𝑚𝜎Sign(sk,m)\rightarrow\sigma: take in a signing key s​k𝑠𝑘sk and message m𝑚m, outputs a signature σ𝜎\sigma.

  • •

    V​e​r​S​i​g​(p​k,m,σ)→b→𝑉𝑒𝑟𝑆𝑖𝑔𝑝𝑘𝑚𝜎𝑏VerSig(pk,m,\sigma)\rightarrow b: take in a verification key p​k𝑝𝑘pk, a messagee m𝑚m and a signature σ𝜎\sigma, output valid or not as b=1,Γ𝑏1Γb=1,0.

We say that the signature scheme is secure if the probability that, given m1,…,mzsubscript𝑚1…subscript𝑚𝑧m_{1},\ldots,m_{z}, an attacker who can query the signing challenger and finds a valid (m′,σ′)superscript𝑚′superscript𝜎′(m^{\prime},\sigma^{\prime}) where m′∉{m1,…,mz}superscript𝑚′subscript𝑚1…subscript𝑚𝑧m^{\prime}\not\in\{m_{1},\ldots,m_{z}\} is negligible.

B.2 Setup phase and distributed key generation

The setup protocol is conceptually simple, as shown in Figure 11. A crucial part of the setup phase is the distributed key generation (DKG). We first describe the algorithms used in DKG.

  • •

    P​V​e​r​i​f​y​(sj,sj′,{Ck}k=Γℓ)→b→𝑃𝑉𝑒𝑟𝑖𝑓𝑦subscript𝑠𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑗′superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐶𝑘𝑘Γℓ𝑏PVerify(s_{j},s_{j}^{\prime},\{C_{k}\}_{k=0}^{\ell})\rightarrow b where b∈{Γ,1}𝑏Γ1b\in\{0,1\}.

Protocol. We give the modified DKG protocol ΠDKGsubscriptΠDKG\Pi_{\text{DKG}} from GJKR-DKG in Figure 12. The participating parties can drop out, as long as ηD+δD<1/3subscript𝜂𝐷subscript𝛿𝐷13\eta_{D}+\delta_{D}<1/3.

Correctness and security. We analyze the properties of ΠDKGsubscriptΠDKG\Pi_{\text{DKG}} in this section. We start by revisiting the correctness and security definitions of GJKR-DKG, and then discuss how our definition differs from theirs because of a weakening of the communication model. In GJKR-DKG, correctness has three folds:

  1. 1.

    All subsets of honest parties define the same unique secret key.

  2. 2.

    All honest parties have the same public key.

  3. 3.

    The secret key is uniformly random.

Security means that no information about the secret key can be learned by the adversary except for what is implied by the public key. For ΠDKGsubscriptΠDKG\Pi_{\text{DKG}}, if the server is honest, then our communication model (§2.3) is equivalent to having a fully synchronous channel, hence in this case the correctness and security properties in the prior work hold. When the server is malicious, we show that ΠDKGsubscriptΠDKG\Pi_{\text{DKG}} satisfies the following correctness (C1, C2, C3, C4) and security (S).

  • C1.

    Each honest party either has no secret at the end or agrees on the same QUAL with other honest parties.

  • C2.

    The agreed QUAL sets defines a unique secret key.

  • C3.

    The secret key defined by QUAL is uniformly random.

  • C4.

    Each honest party, either has no public key, or outputs the same public key with other honest parties.

  • S.

    Malicious parties learns no information about the secret key except for what is implied by the public key.

Lemma 2.

Let the participants in DKG be L𝐿L parties and a server. If δD+ηD<1/3subscript𝛿𝐷subscript𝜂𝐷13\delta_{D}+\eta_{D}<1/3, then under the communication model defined in Section 2.2, protocol ΠDKGsubscriptΠDKG\Pi_{\text{DKG}} (Fig. 12) has properties C1, C2, C3, C4 and S in the presence of a malicious adversary controlling the server and up to ηDsubscript𝜂𝐷\eta_{D} fraction of the parties.

Proof. Since L=3​ℓ+1𝐿3ℓ1L=3\ell+1, and by δD+ηD<1/3subscript𝛿𝐷subscript𝜂𝐷13\delta_{D}+\eta_{D}<1/3, at most ℓℓ\ell are malicious (the dropouts can be treated as malicious parties who do not send the prescribed messages). We first show under which cases the honest parties will have no share. Note that the parties that are excluded from 𝒟2subscript𝒟2\mathcal{D}_{2} are those who are honest but did not receive a complaint against a malicious party who performed wrong sharing; and parties that are excluded from 𝒟3subscript𝒟3\mathcal{D}_{3} are those who have complained at i𝑖i in step (b) but did not receive shares from i𝑖i at this step. If the server drops messages (sent from one online honest party to another) in the above two cases, then in the cross-check step, the honest parties will not receive more than 2​ℓ+12ℓ12\ell+1 QUALs, and hence will abort. In this case, honest parties in the end has no share.

Now we prove C1 by contradiction. Suppose there are two honest parties P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} and P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} at the end of the protocol who holds secrets (not abort) and they have different QUAL. Then this means P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} received at least 2​ℓ+12ℓ12\ell+1 same QUAL sets S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} and P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} received at least same 2​ℓ+12ℓ12\ell+1 QUAL sets S2subscript𝑆2S_{2}. W.l.o.g., assume that there are ℓ−vℓ𝑣\ell-v malicious parties (v≥Γ𝑣Γv\geq 0). In the 2​ℓ+12ℓ12\ell+1 sets S1subscript𝑆1S_{1}, at least ℓ+1+vℓ1𝑣\ell+1+v of them are from honest parties. Similarly, for the 2​ℓ+12ℓ12\ell+1 sets S2subscript𝑆2S_{2}, at least ℓ+1+vℓ1𝑣\ell+1+v are from other honest parties different than above (since an honest party cannot send both S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} and S2subscript𝑆2S_{2}). However, note that we have in total 2​ℓ+1+v2ℓ1𝑣2\ell+1+v honest parties, which derives a contradiction.

Recall that at most ℓℓ\ell parties are malicious, so the QUAL set has at least ℓ+1ℓ1\ell+1 parties, and since we have C1, now C2 is guaranteed. Moreover, since QUAL contains at least one honest party, the secret key is uniform (C3). C4 follows exactly from the work GJKR. The proof for S is the same as GKJR, except that the simulator additionally simulates the agreement protocol in Lemma 3.

Remark. An important difference between ΠDKGsubscriptΠDKG\Pi_{\text{DKG}} and standard DKG protocols is that we allow aborts and allow honest parties to not have shares at the end of the protocol. When some honest parties do not have shares of the secret key, the server is still able to get sum (decryption still works) because malicious parties hold the shares.

B.3 Collection phase

The detailed protocol for each round in the collection phase is described in Figure 13. At the beginning of round t𝑡t, the server notifies the clients who should be involved, namely Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t}. A client who gets a notification can download public keys of its neighbors At​(i)subscript𝐴𝑡𝑖A_{t}(i) from PKI server (the server should tell clients how to map client IDs to the names in PKI). To reduce the overall run time, clients can pre-fetch public keys used in the coming rounds.

B.4 Transfer shares

Every R𝑅R rounds, the current set of decryptors 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} transfer shares of S​K𝑆𝐾SK to a new set of decryptors, 𝒟n​e​wsubscript𝒟𝑛𝑒𝑤\mathcal{D}_{new}. To do so, each u∈𝒟𝑢𝒟u\in\mathcal{D} computes a destination decryptors set 𝒟n​e​wsubscript𝒟𝑛𝑒𝑤\mathcal{D}_{new} for round t𝑡t, by ChooseSet​(v,⌈t/R⌉,L,N)ChooseSet𝑣𝑡𝑅𝐿𝑁\textsc{ChooseSet}(v,\lceil t/R\rceil,L,N). Assume now each decryptor u∈𝒟𝑢𝒟u\in\mathcal{D} holds share susubscript𝑠𝑢s_{u} of S​K𝑆𝐾SK (i.e., there is a polynomial p𝑝p such that p​(u)=su𝑝𝑢subscript𝑠𝑢p(u)=s_{u} and p​(Γ)=S​K𝑝Γ𝑆𝐾p(0)=SK). To transfer its share, each u∈𝒟𝑢𝒟u\in\mathcal{D} acts as a VSS dealer exactly the same as the first part in ΠDKGsubscriptΠDKG\Pi_{\text{DKG}} (Fig.9) to share susubscript𝑠𝑢s_{u} to new decryptor j∈𝒟n​e​w𝑗subscript𝒟𝑛𝑒𝑤j\in\mathcal{D}_{new}. In detail, u𝑢u chooses a polynomial pu∗subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑢p^{*}_{u} of degree ℓℓ\ell and sets pu∗​(Γ)=susubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑢Γsubscript𝑠𝑢p^{*}_{u}(0)=s_{u} and all other coefficients of pu∗subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑢p^{*}_{u} to be random. Then, u𝑢u sends pu∗​(j)subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑢𝑗p^{*}_{u}(j) to each new decryptor j∈𝒟n​e​w𝑗subscript𝒟𝑛𝑒𝑤j\in\mathcal{D}_{new}.

Each new decryptor j∈𝒟n​e​w𝑗subscript𝒟𝑛𝑒𝑤j\in\mathcal{D}_{new} receives the evaluation of the polynomials at point j𝑗j (i.e., pu∗​(j)subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑢𝑗p^{*}_{u}(j) for all u∈𝒟𝑢𝒟u\in\mathcal{D}). The new share of S​K𝑆𝐾SK held by j𝑗j, sj′superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑗′s_{j}^{\prime}, is defined to be a linear combination of the received shares: sj′:=∑u∈𝒟βu⋅pu∗​(j)assignsuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑗′subscript𝑢𝒟⋅subscript𝛽𝑢subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑢𝑗s_{j}^{\prime}:=\sum_{u\in\mathcal{D}}\beta_{u}\cdot p^{*}_{u}(j), where the combination coefficients {βu}u∈𝒟subscriptsubscript𝛽𝑢𝑢𝒟\{\beta_{u}\}_{u\in\mathcal{D}} are constants (given the set 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, we can compute {βu}u∈𝒟subscriptsubscript𝛽𝑢𝑢𝒟\{\beta_{u}\}_{u\in\mathcal{D}}). Note that the same issue about communication model for DKG also exists here, but the same relaxation applies.

Here we require that ηD+δD<1/3subscript𝜂𝐷subscript𝛿𝐷13\eta_{D}+\delta_{D}<1/3 for both 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} and 𝒟n​e​wsubscript𝒟𝑛𝑒𝑤\mathcal{D}_{new}. As a result, each client j𝑗j in a subset 𝒟⊆𝒟n​e​w𝒟subscript𝒟𝑛𝑒𝑤\mathcal{D}\subseteq\mathcal{D}_{new} holds a share su,jsubscript𝑠𝑢𝑗s_{u,j}. For each receiving decryptor j∈𝒟𝑗𝒟j\in\mathcal{D}, it computes sj′=∑u∈𝒟o​l​dβu⋅su,jsuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑗′subscript𝑢subscript𝒟𝑜𝑙𝑑⋅subscript𝛽𝑢subscript𝑠𝑢𝑗s_{j}^{\prime}=\sum_{u\in\mathcal{D}_{old}}\beta_{u}\cdot s_{u,j}, where each βusubscript𝛽𝑢\beta_{u} is some fixed constant.

Since the sharing part is exactly the same as ΠDKGsubscriptΠDKG\Pi_{\text{DKG}} and the share combination happens locally, the same correctness and security argument of DKG applies. Specifically, for correctness, each honest party either has no secret at the end or agrees on the same QUAL with other honest parties; and the QUAL defines the unique same secret key before resharing. For security, a malicious adversary will not learn any information, but can cause the protocol aborts.

Appendix C Requirements on Parameters

C.1 The number of decryptors

In this section, we show how to choose L𝐿L such that, given N,η,δD𝑁𝜂subscript𝛿𝐷N,\eta,\delta_{D}, we can guarantee less than 1/3131/3 of the L𝐿L chosen decryptors are malicious. Note that δDsubscript𝛿𝐷\delta_{D} is given because this can be controlled by the server, i.e., the server can decide how long to wait for the decryptors to respond.

To guarantee 2​δD+ηD<1/32subscript𝛿𝐷subscript𝜂𝐷132\delta_{D}+\eta_{D}<1/3 (Theorem 3), a necessary condition is that η<1/3−2​δD𝜂132subscript𝛿𝐷\eta<1/3-2\delta_{D}. This can be formalized as a probability question: Given N𝑁N clients where η𝜂\eta fraction of them are malicious, and randomly choose L𝐿L clients (decryptors) from them; the malicious clients X𝑋X in decryptors can be upper bounded using Chernoff bound as

Pr⁡[X≥(η+(1/3−2​δD−η))​L]≤e−2​L​(1/3−η−2​δD)2,Pr𝑋𝜂132subscript𝛿𝐷𝜂𝐿superscript𝑒2𝐿superscript13𝜂2subscript𝛿𝐷2\Pr[X\geq(\eta+(1/3-2\delta_{D}-\eta))L]\leq e^{-2L(1/3-\eta-2\delta_{D})^{2}},

For η𝜂\eta and δDsubscript𝛿𝐷\delta_{D} both being 1%, the choice of L=6​Γ𝐿6ΓL=60 (Section 6) gives 1​Γ−61superscriptΓ610^{-6} probability. If we double L𝐿L to be 120, then this guarantees 1​Γ−1​21superscriptΓ1210^{-12} probability.

C.2 Proof of Lemma 1

The algorithm in Figure 1 gives a random graph G​(n,ϵ)𝐺𝑛italic-ϵG(n,\epsilon). A known result in random graphs is, when the edge probability ϵ>(1+ω)​ln⁡nnitalic-ϵ1𝜔𝑛𝑛\epsilon>\frac{(1+\omega)\ln n}{n}, where ω𝜔\omega is an arbitrary positive value, the graph is almost surely connected when n𝑛n is large. Note that in BBGLR, they also use this observation to build the graph that has significant less number of neighbors than a prior work by Bonawitz et al. [11], but in their work since the clients chooses their neighbors, the resulting graph is a biased one; and they guarantee that there is no small isolated components in the graph.

Concretely, from Gilbert [35], let g​(n,ϵ)𝑔𝑛italic-ϵg(n,\epsilon) be the probability that graph G​(n,ϵ)𝐺𝑛italic-ϵG(n,\epsilon) has disconnected components, and it can be recursively computed as

g​(n,ϵ)=1−∑i=1n−1(n−1i−1)​g​(i,ϵ)​(1−ϵ)i​(n−i)​.𝑔𝑛italic-ϵ1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛1binomial𝑛1𝑖1𝑔𝑖italic-ϵsuperscript1italic-ϵ𝑖𝑛𝑖.g(n,\epsilon)=1-\sum_{i=1}^{n-1}\binom{n-1}{i-1}g(i,\epsilon)(1-\epsilon)^{i(n-i)}.

We numerically depict the above upper bound of the probability g​(n,ϵ)𝑔𝑛italic-ϵg(n,\epsilon) for different ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon in Figure 14. For example, when n=1​Γ​2​4𝑛1Γ24n=1024, to ensure less than 1​Γ−61superscriptΓ610^{-6} failure probability, we need ϵ≥Γ​.​Γ​2italic-ϵΓ.Γ2\epsilon\geq 0.02, hence the number of neighbors a client needs when δ=η=Γ​.​Γ​1𝛿𝜂Γ.Γ1\delta=\eta=0.01 is at least ⌈(ϵ+δ+η)​n⌉=4​1italic-ϵ𝛿𝜂𝑛41\lceil(\epsilon+\delta+\eta)n\rceil=41. Recall that when η𝜂\eta and δDsubscript𝛿𝐷\delta_{D} are both 1%, the lower bound for number of decryptors L𝐿L is roughly 60 (Appendix C.1).

Appendix D Security Proofs

D.1 Security definition

We say a protocol ΠΠ\Pi securely realizes ideal functionality ℱℱ\mathcal{F} in the presence of a malicious adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} if there exists a probabilistic polynomial time algorithm, or simulator, 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}, such that for any probabilistic polynomial time 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, the distribution of the output of the real-world execution of ΠΠ\Pi is (statistically or computationally) indistinguishable from the distribution of the output of the ideal-world execution invoking ℱℱ\mathcal{F}: the output of both worlds’ execution includes the inputs and outputs of honest parties the view of the adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. In our proof, we focus on the computational notion of security. Note that 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} in the ideal world has one-time access to ℱℱ\mathcal{F}, and has the inputs of the corrupted parties controlled by 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}.

D.2 Ideal functionalities

We provide ideal functionality for Flamingo in Figure 4. Looking ahead in the proof, we also need to define an ideal functionality for the setup phase and an ideal functionality for a single round in the collection phase, which we give as Figure 3 and Figure 15.

We model the trusted source of initial randomness as a functionality ℱrandsubscriptℱrand\mathcal{F}_{\text{rand}}; that is, a party or ideal functionality on calling ℱrandsubscriptℱrand\mathcal{F}_{\text{rand}} will receive a uniform random value v𝑣v in {Γ,1}λsuperscriptΓ1𝜆\{0,1\}^{\lambda}, where λ𝜆\lambda is the length of the PRG seed.

D.3 Proof of Theorem 1

The ideal functionality ℱsetupsubscriptℱsetup\mathcal{F}_{\text{setup}} for the setup phase is defined in Figure 3. Depending on whether the server is corrupted or not, we have the following two cases.

  1. 1.

    When the server is not corrupted, then the communication model is equivalent to a secure broadcast channel. By security of GJKR, ΠsetupsubscriptΠsetup\Pi_{\text{setup}} securely realizes ℱsetupsubscriptℱsetup\mathcal{F}_{\text{setup}}.

  2. 2.

    When the server is corrupted, we build a simulator for the adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. We start by listing the messages that 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} sees throughout the setup phase:

    • •

      A random value v𝑣v from ℱrandsubscriptℱrand\mathcal{F}_{\text{rand}};

    • •

      All the messages in ΠDKGsubscriptΠDKG\Pi_{\textrm{DKG}} that are sent via the server;

    • •

      All the messages in ΠDKGsubscriptΠDKG\Pi_{\textrm{DKG}} that are seen by the corrupted decryptors.

    The simulator first calls ℱrandsubscriptℱrand\mathcal{F}_{\text{rand}} and receives a value v𝑣v. Then the simulator interacts with 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} acting as the honest decryptors. The simulator aborts if any honest decryptors would abort in ΠDKGsubscriptΠDKG\Pi_{\textrm{DKG}}. There are two ways that 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} can cheat: 1) 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} cheats in ΠDKGsubscriptΠDKG\Pi_{\textrm{DKG}}, and in Appendix B.2, we show the simulator can simulate the view of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}; 2) 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} cheats outside ΠDKGsubscriptΠDKG\Pi_{\textrm{DKG}}, this means 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} chooses a wrong set of decryptors, or it broadcasts wrong signatures. So the simulator aborts as long as it does not receive 2​ℓ+12ℓ12\ell+1 valid signatures on P​K𝑃𝐾PKs signed by the set defined by v𝑣v.

Finally, note that our threat model (§2.3) assumes that the server is also controlled by the adversary, i.e., the first case is not needed here; but it will be useful when we analyze the robust version in Appendix E.1.

D.4 Proof of Theorem 2

The proof for dropout resilience is rather simple: in the setup phase, at most δDsubscript𝛿𝐷\delta_{D} fraction of L𝐿L selected decryptors drop out; then in one round of the collection phase, another δDsubscript𝛿𝐷\delta_{D} fraction of decryptors can drop out. Since 2​δD+ηD<1/32subscript𝛿𝐷subscript𝜂𝐷132\delta_{D}+\eta_{D}<1/3, and 3​ℓ+1=L3ℓ1𝐿3\ell+1=L (Fig. 12), the online decryptors can always help the server to reconstruct the secrets.

D.5 Proof of Theorem 3

We first present the proof for a single round: the collection protocol ΠsumsubscriptΠsum\Pi_{\text{sum}} (Fig. 13) for round t𝑡t securely realizes the ideal functionality ℱsum(t)superscriptsubscriptℱsum𝑡\mathcal{F}_{\text{sum}}^{(t)} (Fig. 15) in the random oracle model. From the ideal functionality ℱsum(t)superscriptsubscriptℱsum𝑡\mathcal{F}_{\text{sum}}^{(t)} we can see that when the server is corrupted, the result is not determined by the actual dropout set 𝒪tsubscript𝒪𝑡\mathcal{O}_{t}, but instead Mtsubscript𝑀𝑡M_{t} sent by the adversary; when Mt=St\𝒪tsubscript𝑀𝑡\subscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝒪𝑡M_{t}=S_{t}\backslash\mathcal{O}_{t} (in this case the adversary does not cheat or the cheating behavior does not affect the output), zt′superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑡′z_{t}^{\prime} learned by the adversary in ℱsum(t)superscriptsubscriptℱsum𝑡\mathcal{F}_{\text{sum}}^{(t)} equals ztsubscript𝑧𝑡z_{t} computed in the protocol ΠsumsubscriptΠsum\Pi_{\text{sum}}. In the robust version (Appendix E.1), we will see that when the server is honest, the result is determined by 𝒪tsubscript𝒪𝑡\mathcal{O}_{t}.

In the proof below for a single round, for simplicity, we omit the round number t𝑡t when there is no ambiguity. We assume the adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} controls a set of clients in [N]delimited-[]𝑁[N], with the constraint 2​δD+ηD<1/32subscript𝛿𝐷subscript𝜂𝐷132\delta_{D}+\eta_{D}<1/3. Denote the set of corrupted clients in [N]delimited-[]𝑁[N] as 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} and as before the set of the decryptors is 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}; the malicious decryptors form a set 𝒞∩𝒟𝒞𝒟\mathcal{C}\cap\mathcal{D} and |𝒞∩𝒟|<L/3𝒞𝒟𝐿3|\mathcal{C}\cap\mathcal{D}|<L/3. From the analysis in Appendix A, we have |𝒞|/|St|≤η𝒞subscript𝑆𝑡𝜂|\mathcal{C}|/|S_{t}|\leq\eta.

Now we construct a simulator 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} in the ideal world that runs 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} as a subroutine. We assume both the simulator 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} and ideal functionality ℱsum(t)superscriptsubscriptℱsum𝑡\mathcal{F}_{\text{sum}}^{(t)} (Fig. 15) have access to an oracle ℛdropsubscriptℛdrop\mathcal{R}_{\text{drop}} that provides the dropout sets 𝒪tsubscript𝒪𝑡\mathcal{O}_{t}. In other words, the dropout set is not provided ahead of the protocol but instead provided during the execution (similar notion appeared in prior work [11]). Assume that in the ideal world, initially a secret key S​K𝑆𝐾SK is shared among at least 2​L/32𝐿32L/3 clients in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. The simulation for round t𝑡t is as follows.

  1. 1.

    𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} received a set 𝒪tsubscript𝒪𝑡\mathcal{O}_{t} from the oracle ℛdropsubscriptℛdrop\mathcal{R}_{\text{drop}}.

  2. 2.

    𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} receives a set Mtsubscript𝑀𝑡M_{t} from the adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}.

  3. 3.

    𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} obtains zt′superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑡′z_{t}^{\prime} from ℱsum(t)superscriptsubscriptℱsum𝑡\mathcal{F}_{\text{sum}}^{(t)}.

  4. 4.

    (Report step) 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} interacts with 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} as in the report step acting as the honest clients i∈Mt\𝒞𝑖\subscript𝑀𝑡𝒞i\in M_{t}\backslash\mathcal{C} with masked inputs x→i′superscriptsubscript→𝑥𝑖′\vec{x}_{i}^{\prime}, such that ∑i∈Mt\𝒞x→i′=zt′subscript𝑖\subscript𝑀𝑡𝒞superscriptsubscript→𝑥𝑖′superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑡′\sum_{i\in M_{t}\backslash\mathcal{C}}\vec{x}_{i}^{\prime}=z_{t}^{\prime}.

    Here the input vector x→i′superscriptsubscript→𝑥𝑖′\vec{x}_{i}^{\prime} and the mask misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i} are generated by 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} itself, and the pairwise secrets are obtained by querying the PKI.

  5. 5.

    (Cross-check step) 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} interacts with 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} acting as honest decryptors as in the cross-check step.

  6. 6.

    (Reconstruction step) 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} interacts with 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} acting as honest decryptors in the reconstruction step, where 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} uses the shares of the secret key S​K𝑆𝐾SK to perform decryption of honest parties.

  7. 7.

    In the above steps, if all the honest decryptors would abort in the protocol prescription then 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} sends abort to ℱsum(t)superscriptsubscriptℱsum𝑡\mathcal{F}_{\text{sum}}^{(t)}, outputs whatever 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} outputs and halts.

We construct a series of hybrid execution, starting from the real world to the ideal world execution.

Hybrid 1. The view of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} in the real world execution is the same as the view of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} in the ideal world when 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} would have the actual inputs of honest parties, {x→i}i∈St\(𝒞∪𝒪t)subscriptsubscript→𝑥𝑖𝑖\subscript𝑆𝑡𝒞subscript𝒪𝑡\{\vec{x}_{i}\}_{i\in S_{t}\backslash(\mathcal{C}\cup\mathcal{O}_{t})}, the pairwise and individual masks, and the shares of the secret key S​K𝑆𝐾SK. (𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} in fact would know S​K𝑆𝐾SK in full because 3​ℓ+1=L3ℓ1𝐿3\ell+1=L and that the number of honest parties is 2​ℓ+12ℓ12\ell+1 or more.)

Hybrid 2. 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} now instead of using the actual secret key s𝑠s, it replaces s𝑠s with 0 and sends the corresponding |𝒞∩𝒟|<L/3𝒞𝒟𝐿3|\mathcal{C}\cap\mathcal{D}|<L/3 shares of 0 in ℤqsubscriptℤ𝑞\mathbb{Z}_{q} to 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. The joint distribution of less than L/3𝐿3L/3 shares (recall that the threshold is ℓℓ\ell where 3​ℓ+1=L3ℓ1𝐿3\ell+1=L), from the property of Shamir secret sharing, for s𝑠s and ΓΓ are the same. Hence this hybrid has identical distribution to the previous hybrid.

Hybrid 3. 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} now instead of using the actual pairwise masks between honest parties, it samples a random pairwise mask ri,j′superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑗′r_{i,j}^{\prime} from {Γ,1}λsuperscriptΓ1𝜆\{0,1\}^{\lambda} and computes the corresponding ElGamal ciphertext as (cΓ′,c1′)superscriptsubscript𝑐Γ′superscriptsubscript𝑐1′(c_{0}^{\prime},c_{1}^{\prime}). 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} does not change the pairwise mask between a client controlled by 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} and an honest client (such pairwise mask can be obtained by querying PKI to get gajsuperscript𝑔subscript𝑎𝑗g^{a_{j}} for an honest client j𝑗j, and compute (gaj)aisuperscriptsuperscript𝑔subscript𝑎𝑗subscript𝑎𝑖(g^{a_{j}})^{a_{i}} for malicious client i𝑖i). We argue that 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}’s view in this hybrid is computationally indistinguishable from the previous one as below.

First, we need to assume the mapping from 𝔾𝔾\mathbb{G} to {Γ,1}λsuperscriptΓ1𝜆\{0,1\}^{\lambda} is a random oracle. To specify, in the real world, the mask ri,jsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑗r_{i,j} is computed from the mapping on gai​ajsuperscript𝑔subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑎𝑗g^{a_{i}a_{j}}; and in the ideal world the mask ri,j′superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑗′r_{i,j}^{\prime} is randomly sampled. Let Mtsubscript𝑀𝑡M_{t} be the set of online clients that 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} labels in the real world (recall the server is controlled by 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}). 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} in both worlds observes PRF​(ri,j,t)PRFsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑗𝑡\textrm{PRF}(r_{i,j},t) between a client i𝑖i out of Mtsubscript𝑀𝑡M_{t} and a client j𝑗j in Mtsubscript𝑀𝑡M_{t}, hence we require ri,jsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑗r_{i,j} to be random as a PRF key.

Second, 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} in the ideal world does not observe the pairwise masks between clients in Mtsubscript𝑀𝑡M_{t}, but only the ciphertexts generated from ri,j′superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑗′r_{i,j}^{\prime} for those clients; and the distribution of the ciphertexts is computationally indistinguishable from what 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} observed from the real world by the security of ElGamal encryption (Definition 2).

Hybrid 4. 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} now instead of using symmetric encryption (SymAuthEnc) of the shares of the actual individual mask misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i}, it uses the symmetric encryption of a randomly sampled mi′superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑖′m_{i}^{\prime} from {Γ,1}λsuperscriptΓ1𝜆\{0,1\}^{\lambda} as the individual mask. Looking ahead in the proof, we also need to model the PRG as a random oracle ℛPRGsubscriptℛPRG\mathcal{R}_{\textrm{PRG}} that can be thought of as a “perfect PRG” (see more details in a prior work [11]). For all i∈Mt/𝒞𝑖subscript𝑀𝑡𝒞i\in M_{t}/\mathcal{C}, 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} samples V​e​ci𝑉𝑒subscript𝑐𝑖Vec_{i} at random and programs ℛPRGsubscriptℛPRG\mathcal{R}_{\textrm{PRG}} to set PRG​(mi′)PRGsuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑖′\textrm{PRG}(m_{i}^{\prime}) as

PRG​(mi′)=V​e​ci−x→i−∑±PRG​(ri,j′),PRGsuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑖′plus-or-minus𝑉𝑒subscript𝑐𝑖subscript→𝑥𝑖PRGsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑗′\textrm{PRG}(m_{i}^{\prime})=Vec_{i}-\vec{x}_{i}-\sum\pm\textrm{PRG}(r_{i,j}^{\prime}),

where the vectors V​e​ci𝑉𝑒subscript𝑐𝑖Vec_{i}’s are vectors observed in the real world. The view of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} regarding V​e​ci𝑉𝑒subscript𝑐𝑖Vec_{i}’s in this hybrid is statistically indistinguishable to that in the previous hybrid.

Moreover, 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} learns the misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i} in the clear for those i∈Mt𝑖subscript𝑀𝑡i\in M_{t} in both worlds, and the distributions of those misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i}’s in the ideal and real world are identical; for those misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i}’s where i∉Mt𝑖subscript𝑀𝑡i\not\in M_{t} that 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} should not learn, from the semantic security of the symmetric encryption scheme (Definition 3), and the threshold ℓ<L/3ℓ𝐿3\ell<L/3, 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}’s view in this hybrid is computationally indistinguishable from the previous one.

Hybrid 5. 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} now instead of programming the oracle ℛPRGsubscriptℛPRG\mathcal{R}_{\textrm{PRG}} as in the previous hybrid, it programs the oracle as

PRG​(mi′)=V​e​ci−x→i′−∑±PRG​(ri,j′),PRGsuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑖′plus-or-minus𝑉𝑒subscript𝑐𝑖superscriptsubscript→𝑥𝑖′PRGsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑗′\textrm{PRG}(m_{i}^{\prime})=Vec_{i}-\vec{x}_{i}^{\prime}-\sum\pm\textrm{PRG}(r_{i,j}^{\prime}),

where x→i′superscriptsubscript→𝑥𝑖′\vec{x}_{i}^{\prime}’s are chosen such that ∑i∈Mt\𝒞x→i=∑i∈Mt\𝒞x→i′subscript𝑖\subscript𝑀𝑡𝒞subscript→𝑥𝑖subscript𝑖\subscript𝑀𝑡𝒞superscriptsubscript→𝑥𝑖′\sum_{i\in M_{t}\backslash\mathcal{C}}\vec{x}_{i}=\sum_{i\in M_{t}\backslash\mathcal{C}}\vec{x}_{i}^{\prime}. From Lemma 6.1 in a prior work [11] under the same setting, the distribution of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}’s view in this hybrid is statistically indistinguishable to that in the previous hybrid, except probability 2−κsuperscript2𝜅2^{-\kappa}: if the graph becomes disconnected or there is an isolated node after removing 𝒪tsubscript𝒪𝑡\mathcal{O}_{t} and 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} from Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t}, then the server learns xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} in the clear and thus can distinguish between the two worlds. When 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} cheats by submitting Mtsubscript𝑀𝑡M_{t} to 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} where the graph formed by nodes in Mtsubscript𝑀𝑡M_{t} is not connected, 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} simulates honest decryptors and output abort. In this case, the distribution of 𝒜′​ssuperscript𝒜′𝑠\mathcal{A}^{\prime}s view in the ideal world is the same as that in the real world.

Hybrid 7. Same as the previous hybrid, except that the label messages r​e​q𝑟𝑒𝑞req from honest decryptors in the last step are replaced with the offline/online labels obtained from the oracle. In all steps, 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} would cheat by sending invalid signatures to 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}; in this case 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} will abort. In the cross-check and reconstruction steps, there are following ways that 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} would cheat here:

  1. 1.

    𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} sends multiple different Mtsubscript𝑀𝑡M_{t}’s to ℱsumsubscriptℱsum\mathcal{F}_{\text{sum}}. 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} in the ideal world will simulate the protocol in Lemma 3 below, and outputs whatever the protocol outputs.

  2. 2.

    𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} sends to ℱsumsubscriptℱsum\mathcal{F}_{\text{sum}} a set Mtsubscript𝑀𝑡M_{t} with less than (1−δ)​nt1𝛿subscript𝑛𝑡(1-\delta)n_{t} clients, or the clients in Mtsubscript𝑀𝑡M_{t} are disconnected, or there is a client in Mtsubscript𝑀𝑡M_{t} with less than ηksuperscript𝜂𝑘\eta^{k} online neighbors. In this case, 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} will abort, which is the same as in the real-world execution.

The last hybrid is exactly the ideal world execution. To better analyze the simulation succeeding probability, we use κ1subscript𝜅1\kappa_{1} to denote the security parameter for the graph connectivity (Lemma 1) and use κ2subscript𝜅2\kappa_{2} to denote the security parameter for the third checking in the cross-check round (§4.4). The simulation can fail in two ways: 1) The graph gets disconnected (even when the server is honest); 2) There exists a client in Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t} such that all of its online neighbors are malicious. The former happens with probability 2−κ1superscript2subscript𝜅12^{-\kappa_{1}}. The latter is bounded by n⋅2−κ2⋅𝑛superscript2subscript𝜅2n\cdot 2^{-\kappa_{2}}: the probability that the opposite event of 2) happens is (1−ηk)n≈1−n​ηksuperscript1superscript𝜂𝑘𝑛1𝑛superscript𝜂𝑘(1-\eta^{k})^{n}\approx 1-n\eta^{k} (assuming ηksuperscript𝜂𝑘\eta^{k} is very small). Thus the failure probability n​ηk≤n⋅2−κ2𝑛superscript𝜂𝑘⋅𝑛superscript2subscript𝜅2n\eta^{k}\leq n\cdot 2^{-\kappa_{2}}. This completes the proof that for any single round t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T], the protocol ΠsumsubscriptΠsum\Pi_{\text{sum}} for round t𝑡t securely realizes ℱsum(t)superscriptsubscriptℱsum𝑡\mathcal{F}_{\text{sum}}^{(t)} when δD+ηD<1/3subscript𝛿𝐷subscript𝜂𝐷13\delta_{D}+\eta_{D}<1/3, except probability 2−κ1+n⋅2−κ2≤n⋅2−κ+1superscript2subscript𝜅1⋅𝑛superscript2subscript𝜅2⋅𝑛superscript2𝜅12^{-\kappa_{1}}+n\cdot 2^{-\kappa_{2}}\leq n\cdot 2^{-\kappa+1}, where κ=min⁡{κ1,κ2}𝜅subscript𝜅1subscript𝜅2\kappa=\min\{\kappa_{1},\kappa_{2}\}.

Lemma 3.

Assume there exists a PKI and a secure signature scheme; there are 3​ℓ+13ℓ13\ell+1 parties with at most ℓℓ\ell colluding malicious parties. Each party has an input bit of 0 or 1 from a server. Then there exists a one-round protocol for honest parties to decide if the server sent the same value to all the honest parties.

Proof.

If an honest party receives 2​ℓ+12ℓ12\ell+1 or more messages with the same value, then it means the server sends to all honest parties the same value. If an honest party receives less than 2​ℓ+12ℓ12\ell+1 messages with the same value, it will abort; in this case the server must have sent different messages to different honest parties. ∎

Remark. The above analysis of the agreement protocol shows where the threshold 1/3131/3 comes from. Consider the case where the threshold is 1/2 and 2​ℓ+1=L2ℓ1𝐿2\ell+1=L. For a target client, the (malicious) server can tell ℓ/2ℓ2\ell/2 decryptors that the client is online and tell another ℓ/2+1ℓ21\ell/2+1 decryptors that the client is offline. Then combined with the ℓℓ\ell malicious decryptors’ shares, the server has ℓ/2+ℓℓ2ℓ\ell/2+\ell shares to reconstruct individual mask, and ℓ/2+1+ℓℓ21ℓ\ell/2+1+\ell shares to reeconstruct the pairwise mask.

Multi-round security. Our threat model assumes that 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} controls η​N𝜂𝑁\eta N clients throughout T𝑇T rounds (§2.3). There are two things we need to additionally consider on top of the single-round proof: 1) the set Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t} is generated from PRG, and 2) the pairwise mask hi,j,tsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑗𝑡h_{i,j,t} computed from PRF​(ri,j,t)PRFsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑗𝑡\textrm{PRF}(r_{i,j},t). For the former, we program ℛPRGsubscriptℛPRG\mathcal{R}_{\textrm{PRG}} (like the single-round proof) such that the ChooseSet outputs Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t}.

Now we analyze the per-round pairwise masks. Let the distribution of the view of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} in round t𝑡t be ΔtsubscriptΔ𝑡\Delta_{t}. We next show that if there exists an adversary ℬℬ\mathcal{B}, and two round number t1,t2∈[T]subscript𝑡1subscript𝑡2delimited-[]𝑇t_{1},t_{2}\in[T] such that ℬℬ\mathcal{B} can distinguish between Δt1subscriptΔsubscript𝑡1\Delta_{t_{1}} and Δt2subscriptΔsubscript𝑡2\Delta_{t_{2}}, then we can construct an adversary ℬ′superscriptℬ′\mathcal{B}^{\prime} who can break PRF security. We call the challenger in PRF security game simply as challenger. There are two worlds (specified by b=Γ𝑏Γb=0 or 111) for the PRF game. When b=Γ𝑏Γb=0, the challenger uses a random function; when b=1𝑏1b=1, the challenger uses PRF and a random key for the PRF. We construct ℬ′superscriptℬ′\mathcal{B}^{\prime} as follows. On input t1,t2subscript𝑡1subscript𝑡2t_{1},t_{2} from ℬℬ\mathcal{B}, ℬ′superscriptℬ′\mathcal{B}^{\prime} asks challenger for hi,j,t1subscriptℎ𝑖𝑗subscript𝑡1h_{i,j,t_{1}} for all clients i𝑖i and j𝑗j, and round t1,t2subscript𝑡1subscript𝑡2t_{1},t_{2}. Then ℬ′superscriptℬ′\mathcal{B}^{\prime} creates the messages computed from hi,j,tsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑗𝑡h_{i,j,t}’s as protocol ΠsumsubscriptΠsum\Pi_{\text{sum}} prescribed; it generates two views Δt1,Δt2subscriptΔsubscript𝑡1subscriptΔsubscript𝑡2\Delta_{t_{1}},\Delta_{t_{2}} and sends to ℬℬ\mathcal{B}. ℬ′superscriptℬ′\mathcal{B^{\prime}} outputs whatever ℬℬ\mathcal{B} outputs.

Failure probability for T𝑇T rounds. For a single round, we already showed that protocol Πsum(t)superscriptsubscriptΠsum𝑡\Pi_{\text{sum}}^{(t)} securely realizes ℱsum(t)superscriptsubscriptℱsum𝑡\mathcal{F}_{\text{sum}}^{(t)} except probability p=n⋅2−κ+1𝑝⋅𝑛superscript2𝜅1p=n\cdot 2^{-\kappa+1}. The probability that for all the T𝑇T rounds the protocol is secure is therefore 1−(1−p)T1superscript1𝑝𝑇1-(1-p)^{T}, which is approximately 1−T⋅p1⋅𝑇𝑝1-T\cdot p when T⋅p≪1much-less-than⋅𝑇𝑝1T\cdot p\ll 1. Therefore, the probability of failure (there exists a round that fails the simulation) is T​n​2−κ+1𝑇𝑛superscript2𝜅1Tn2^{-\kappa+1}.

Appendix E Extension for Robustness

E.1 Robust protocol

As discussed in Section 9, we want the protocol to additionally guarantee robustness when the server is honest. Figure 16 gives the abstraction of robustness. Specifically, our robust version Πsum-robustsubscriptΠsum-robust\Pi_{\text{sum-robust}} has two key properties different from ΠsumsubscriptΠsum\Pi_{\text{sum}}: (1) client inputs are fixed after submitting their vectors in the report step; (i.e., malicious decryptors have no way to change the client inputs); (2) when the server is honest, the malicious clients cannot cause the protocol to abort, and the protocol will always output a sum of inputs from online clients. We treat clients who misbehave in the report step as equivalent to changing their inputs. We emphasize that this type of robustness is weaker than the robustness notion in other works [24, 50], and is practically meaningful only if correct computation in the report step and input validation are ensured.

We now describe two key changes to ΠsumsubscriptΠsum\Pi_{\text{sum}} that together bring robustness. The full description of Πsum-robustsubscriptΠsum-robust\Pi_{\text{sum-robust}} is given as Figure 18, where we highlight the changes from ΠsumsubscriptΠsum\Pi_{\text{sum}} in Figure 13.

Using public-key encryption for both types of seeds. Instead of using symmetric encryption for the shares of mi,tsubscript𝑚𝑖𝑡m_{i,t}, each client encrypts mi,tsubscript𝑚𝑖𝑡m_{i,t} directly (but not the shares) using ElGamal encryption. This reduces the number of ciphertexts appended to the masked vector compared to ΠsumsubscriptΠsum\Pi_{\text{sum}}; but more importantly, later we will see how it combines with another technique (zero-knowledge proof for discrete log) to bring robustness. See the details in the report step of Figure 18. This change in the report step will bring a change in the reconstruction step that the decryptors do threshold decryption on ciphertext mi,tsubscript𝑚𝑖𝑡m_{i,t}, instead of decrypting the shares of mi,tsubscript𝑚𝑖𝑡m_{i,t} using symmetric keys.

Zero-knowledge proof in decryption. In the reconstruction step, in addition to decrypting, each decryptor u𝑢u, for each ciphertext (cΓ,c1)subscript𝑐Γsubscript𝑐1(c_{0},c_{1}), proves to the server that logcΓ(cΓ)su=logggsu\log_{c_{0}}(c_{0})^{s_{u}}=\log_{g}g^{s_{u}}, where gsusuperscript𝑔subscript𝑠𝑢g^{s_{u}} is known to the server. Note that gsusuperscript𝑔subscript𝑠𝑢g^{s_{u}} can be generated in the DKG along the way in the setup phase and stored by the server.

To prove that logcΓ(cΓ)su=logggsu\log_{c_{0}}(c_{0})^{s_{u}}=\log_{g}g^{s_{u}}, each decryptor chooses a random β∈ℤq𝛽subscriptℤ𝑞\beta\in\mathbb{Z}_{q} and sends to the server cΓβ,gβsuperscriptsubscript𝑐Γ𝛽superscript𝑔𝛽c_{0}^{\beta},g^{\beta}. The server then sends to the decryptor a challenge e∈ℤq𝑒subscriptℤ𝑞e\in\mathbb{Z}_{q}. The decryptor computes z=su⋅e+β𝑧⋅subscript𝑠𝑢𝑒𝛽z=s_{u}\cdot e+\beta and sends z𝑧z to the server. The sever checks that (cΓsu)e⋅(cΓ)β=cΓz⋅superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑐Γsubscript𝑠𝑢𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑐Γ𝛽superscriptsubscript𝑐Γ𝑧(c_{0}^{s_{u}})^{e}\cdot(c_{0})^{\beta}=c_{0}^{z} and (gsu)e⋅gβ=gz⋅superscriptsuperscript𝑔subscript𝑠𝑢𝑒superscript𝑔𝛽superscript𝑔𝑧(g^{s_{u}})^{e}\cdot g^{\beta}=g^{z}. We use Fiat-Shamir transform to make the proof non-interactive.

Due to this proof of decryption, the server can exclude bogus partial decryptions from malicious decryptors; since the sharing polynomial for secret key s𝑠s is of degree ℓℓ\ell and there are at least 2​ℓ+12ℓ12\ell+1 honest online decryptors, the server is always able to reconstruct the result.

E.2 Proof of the robust protocol

Let ΨTsubscriptΨ𝑇\Psi_{T} be the sequential execution of ΠsetupsubscriptΠsetup\Pi_{\text{setup}} (Fig.11) and the T𝑇T-round Πsum-robustsubscriptΠsum-robust\Pi_{\text{sum-robust}}.

Theorem 4 (Security of Flamingo extension).

Let the security parameter be κ𝜅\kappa. Let δ,δD,η,ηD𝛿subscript𝛿𝐷𝜂subscript𝜂𝐷\delta,\delta_{D},\eta,\eta_{D} be threat model parameters as defined (§5.1,§5.2). Let ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon be the graph generation parameter (Fig.1). Let n𝑛n be the number of clients in summation in each round. Assuming the existence of a PKI, a trusted source of initial randomness, a PRG, a PRF, an asymmetric encryption AsymEnc, a symmetric SymAuthEnc, and a signature scheme, if 2​δD+ηD<1/32subscript𝛿𝐷subscript𝜂𝐷132\delta_{D}+\eta_{D}<1/3 and ϵ≥ϵ∗italic-ϵsuperscriptitalic-ϵ\epsilon\geq\epsilon^{*} (Lemma 1), then under the communication model defined in §2.2, protocol ΨTsubscriptΨ𝑇\Psi_{T} securely computes functionality ℱmal-robustsubscriptℱmal-robust\mathcal{F}_{\text{mal-robust}} (Fig.16) in the presence of a malicious adversary controlling η𝜂\eta fraction of the N𝑁N clients (or including the server), except probability T​n⋅2−κ+1⋅𝑇𝑛superscript2𝜅1Tn\cdot 2^{-\kappa+1}.

Proof.

We present our proof for the two cases: the server is corrupted by 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} or the server is honest.

When the server is corrupted. When the server is corrupted, we aim to show that the protocol can securely realize ℱsum(t)superscriptsubscriptℱsum𝑡\mathcal{F}_{\text{sum}}^{(t)} in the (b) case. Now 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} corrupts a set of clients (as the above case) and the server. The construction of simulator 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} in the ideal world and the following hyrbid arguments is the same as Appendix D.5.

When the server is not corrupted. We construct a simulator 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} in the ideal world that runs 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} as a subroutine.

  1. 1.

    𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} obtains ztsubscript𝑧𝑡z_{t} from ℱsum-robust(t)superscriptsubscriptℱsum-robust𝑡\mathcal{F}_{\text{sum-robust}}^{(t)} (Fig.17).

  2. 2.

    𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} received a set 𝒪tsubscript𝒪𝑡\mathcal{O}_{t} from ℛdropsubscriptℛdrop\mathcal{R}_{\text{drop}} (see Appendix D.5).

  3. 3.

    (Report step) 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} computes offline/online labels from the set 𝒪tsubscript𝒪𝑡\mathcal{O}_{t}, and interact with 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} acting as the server. Here the collected masked inputs are all zeros and the seeds for the masks are generated by 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} itself.

  4. 4.

    (Cross-check step) 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} acts as honest decryptors in the cross-check step, and if all the honest decryptors would abort in the protocol prescription then 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} outputs whatever 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} outputs, and sends abort to ℱsum(t)superscriptsubscriptℱsum𝑡\mathcal{F}_{\text{sum}}^{(t)} and halts.

  5. 5.

    (Reconstruction step) 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} acts as the server in the reconstruction step, if the server would abort in the protocol prescription, then 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} outputs whatever 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} outputs, and sends abort to ℱsum-robust(t)superscriptsubscriptℱsum-robust𝑡\mathcal{F}_{\text{sum-robust}}^{(t)} and halts.

We construct a series of hybrid execution, starting from the real world to the ideal world execution.

Hybrid 1. The view of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} in the real world execution is the same as the view of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} in the ideal world when 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} would have the actual inputs of honest parties, {x→i}i∈St\𝒞subscriptsubscript→𝑥𝑖𝑖\subscript𝑆𝑡𝒞\{\vec{x}_{i}\}_{i\in S_{t}\backslash\mathcal{C}}, the masks, and the shares of the secret key S​K=s𝑆𝐾𝑠SK=s (𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} in fact would know the s𝑠s in full because of the threshold requirement 3​ℓ+1=L3ℓ1𝐿3\ell+1=L and 2​δD+ηD<1/32subscript𝛿𝐷subscript𝜂𝐷132\delta_{D}+\eta_{D}<1/3).

Hybrid 2. 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} now instead of using the actual secret key s𝑠s, it replaces s𝑠s with 0 and sends the corresponding |𝒞∩𝒟|<L/3𝒞𝒟𝐿3|\mathcal{C}\cap\mathcal{D}|<L/3 shares of 0 in ℤqsubscriptℤ𝑞\mathbb{Z}_{q} to 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. This hybrid has identical distribution to the previous hybrid from the property of Shamir secret sharing.

Hybrid 3. 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} now instead of using the actual masks of honest parties, it replaces each mask with a uniformly random mask generated by 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} itself. This hybrid has identical distribution to the previous hybrid.

Hybrid 4. 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} now instead of using the actual inputs of honest parties {x→i}i∈St\𝒞subscriptsubscript→𝑥𝑖𝑖\subscript𝑆𝑡𝒞\{\vec{x}_{i}\}_{i\in S_{t}\backslash\mathcal{C}}, it replaces each input vector with all zeros. Note that either the masked vectors not the vectors in the clear are seen by 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. This hybrid has identical distribution to the previous hybrid.

Hybrid 5. Same as the previous hybrid, except that the label messages from honest decryptors in the last step are replaced with the offline/online labels obtained from ℛdropsubscriptℛdrop\mathcal{R}_{\text{drop}}. This hybrid is the ideal world execution, and the view of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} in this hybrid is identical to the previous hybrid.

What left to show is that we need to show that in the simulation in the ideal world, 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} will not abort. In simulation step 4, from our threshold requirement L=3​ℓ+1𝐿3ℓ1L=3\ell+1 and Lemma 3, 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} will not abort because the server sends the same r​e​q𝑟𝑒𝑞req to 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. In simulation step 5, 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} will only abort if more than 1/3131/3 of decryptors fail the zero-knowledge proof. This cannot happen because the 2​δD+ηD<1/32subscript𝛿𝐷subscript𝜂𝐷132\delta_{D}+\eta_{D}<1/3.

Combined with our analysis for the setup phase when the server is honest (Appendix B.2), we conclude that ΨTsubscriptΨ𝑇\Psi_{T} securely realizes ℱmal-robustsubscriptℱmal-robust\mathcal{F}_{\text{mal-robust}} in the random oracle model. ∎

Comparison with BBGLR. When the server is honest, both BBGLR and Flamingo (without robustness) has no guaranteed output delivery; a malicious server in BBGLR can learn several subsets of sum (§2.3), while in Flamingo a malicious server learns a single sum from at least 1−η−δ1𝜂𝛿1-\eta-\delta fraction of clients (§5, Fig.4). The robust version of Flamingo improves over Flamingo in the honest-server case: the output delivery is guaranteed (§E.2).

Another difference is the selection of clients per round, which is orthogonal to the single-round protocol design. A malicious server may select a set of clients (Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t}) with many being malicious, and this violates the parameter constraints on η𝜂\eta in BBGLR, and hence the server will learn the sum of inputs from a small number of honest clients; in contrast, in this setting, the server in Flamingo will obtain a random vector. However, the tradeoff (§10) is that BBGLR tolerates adaptive adversaries across rounds but Flamingo does not.
